summary: The project manager briefed the team on some new requirements to consider when designing the remote. The user interface designer presented two existing products and discussed what was wrong with each product. The team discussed how to create a remote which did not include the problems present in the existing products presented by the interface specialist. The marketing expert presented consumer preferences and requirements and the team discussed who their target demographic should be and whether to include speech recognition in their product. The industrial designer discussed the interior workings of a remote and the team discussed various options for components and energy sources. The team then discussed features to include in the remote and what they could do to figure out how to categorize them.
actions: The industrial designer will work on the components concept. The user interface designer will work on the user interface. The marketing expert will work on trend watching
decisions: The team will not work with teletext. The remote will only control televisions. The corporate color and design must be incorporated into the design of the remote. The remote will have buttons for the following functions: on and off, channel up and down, volume up and down, and entering channel numbers. The remote has to look good and be easy to use. The target demographic is people aged fifteen to thirty five. The remote will use an infra-red sensor. The remote will use regular batteries.
problems: How to categorize the functions on the remote. How to implement the categorization of functions in the design of the remote. Defining a target demographic. Whether to include speech recognition as a feature in the remote. How to incorporate more advanced functions into the remote while keeping the design and usability of the remote simple.

[ABSTRACT]   Write one paragraph of coherent text to summarize the meeting as a whole from your role's perspective.

During this third meeting of our design team we set ourselves to the task of using reports from each team member to make decisions on the design concept for the next stages of planning.  The information brought to the meeting included market trend research, available cosmetic features for the unit and a specific user interface proposal.  
The challenge during this meeting was to begin incorporating as many of the production goals as possible in one concept.  The decisions made were done in great haste as time was limited.  We settled on a design using an "8" shape, with a jog-dial for channel selection, a concealed audio control compartment, lemon-lime colour scheme and backlighting.  It was also decided that if possible, the unit would be kinetic powered.  My feeling is that not enough time or focus was spent developing the two top design priorities: fashionable look-and-feel,  and high-tech innovation.

ppt.content:
Components Design
Presented by: David, Industrial Designer
Method
Specify a base implementation from which to kick start ideas and get the meeting talking
Collect feedback from the other team members
Incorporate into design or start from scratch if necessary
Components
User Interface
Buttons: push and scroll wheel
Display: LCD Display
Look & Feel
Cases: curved or flat
Materials: plastic, rubber, wood or titanium
Other Components
Logic  simple, regular, advanced (all have a built in transmitter)
Power  battery, hand dynamo, kinetic, solar
Personal Preferences
Small, slim compact handheld device
Use less and simple components  impacts quantity of functions we want to fufill and production costs

Working Design
Presented by: David, Industrial Designer
Method
Define a list of requirements for the remote control
Create personal list of requirements
Dream up a solution to the requirements (Problems!)
Gather requirements from Team & other sources
Dream up new, better, funkier ideas
Iteratively bounce ideas off the wall and refine
Findings
Electrical energy powers transmitter, input device and logic chip to provide a unit that checks for user input and responds to input
When user enters input (eg. pushes button) the input is captured and sent to logic
Logic interprets the input and issues an appropriate signal to the reciever based on users choice of input
Reciever on the other end (often an external device we have no control over)
Components
Personal Preferences
http://messenger/ami_dev/InspirationID1.htm

Interface Concept
Presented by: Craig, User Interface Designer
Method
Online research
Review existing controls
Read user reviews of these
User Evaluation
Suggestions on 
Size
Shape
Button location
Findings
Most controls are of Large Square Brick type design  not attractive nor comfortable
Most controls are dark colours  easily lost
Inconsistent colour scheme / icons which can confuse user
Personal Preferences
Standard colour coding eg red button for standby
Large, easy to use and identify buttons  but not huge
Intuitive markings on buttons eg volume up shouldnt be V
Easily visible colour (if possible with corporate colour scheme)
Personal Preferences
Extra features will be hidden by hinged opening mechanism  something like a tin pencil case
Voice activated options should always have a button based alternative
Ergonomic & attractive shape overall  Big Square Block is ugly
Voice control confirms action by talking back
Issue
Where should corporate slogan go?
How flexible is colour scheme?

Technical Functions Design
Presented by: Craig,  User Interface Designer
Method
Research online
Look at existing products
Would ask other users for opinions
Will do so at end of meeting
Findings
Many controls too complicated
Too many buttons can confuse user
Confusing labelling is bad eg PROG/PRG
Simplicity good
but can lead to clunky design
Hard to access advanced funcitons eg slow motion
Personal Preferences
Prefer simplicity and attractive look to lots of advanced functions
Advanced functions should be available but not directly accessible to reduce confusion
Your preferences
Look at example remotes
Favourite features?
Dislikes?
Required functions?

Functional Design meeting
Presented by: Laura, Project Manager
Agenda
Opening
Project Manager = secretary (minutes)
New project requirements
3 presentations
Decision on remote control functions
Closing (we have 40 minutes!)
Closing
Now: lunch break
Then 30 minutes of individual work
PM: puts minutes in Project Documents folder
Individual actions
ID: the components concept 
UID: the user interface concept 
ME: trend watching 
Specific instructions will be sent to you by your personal coach.

Evaluation criteria
Presented by: Andrew Stokes-Rees, Marketing Expert
Method of Evaluation 
Product evaluation based on original market research 
Based on design goals (i.e. company logo)
Together lets rate (1 high 7 low)

Rating  1 is most true
Remote control conforms to stylish look and feel?
Remote control conforms to high-tech innovation?
Style reflects a fruit inspired colour?
Design is simple to use, simple in features
Construction is soft and spongy?
Company logo is included?
Within budget?  
Refining Design
Should we be thinking more 3 dimensional?
Could our design involve a series of colours available?
Should we go with vibrant colour or earthy tones?

Functional Requirements
Presented by: Andrew Stokes-Rees, Marketing Expert
Method
Look at research on customer needs
Brainstorm trends
Connect with company vision
Putting fashion into electronics
Prioritise design features
Begin planning marketing identity and marketing strategy
Findings
Users dislike the look-and-feel of current remote controls:
75% of users find most remote controls ugly 
80% of users would spend more money when a remote control would look fancy 
Current remote controls do not match well the operating behavior of the user 
75% of users said they zap a lot 
50% of users say they only use 10% of the buttons 
Personal Preferences
The biggest frustrations users expressed:
Remote controls are often lost somewhere in the room (50%) 
It takes too much time to learn how to use a new remote control (34%) 
Remote controls are bad for RSI (26%) 
Features
The majority of adults would pay more for voice recognition
Users find it ugly
Most features get used very little
Controllers get lost 	
Locator beep

Craig: some controls could be hidden

Method

Read user reviews of these
User Evaluation

How flexible is colour scheme?

Technical Functions Design
Presented by: Craig,  User Interface Designer
Method
Research online
Look at existing products
Would ask other users for opinions
Will do so at end of meeting
Findings
Many controls too complicated
Too many buttons can confuse user
Confusing labelling is bad eg PROG/PRG
Simplicity good
but can lead to clunky design
Hard to access advanced funcitons eg slow motion
Personal Preferences
Prefer simplicity and attractive look to lots of advanced functions
Advanced functions should be available but not directly accessible to reduce confusion
Your preferences
Look at example remotes
Favourite features?
Dislikes?
Required functions?

Trend Watching
Presented by: Andrew Stokes-Rees
Method
1-Develop a broad understanding of market trends based on research
2 - Identify trends that will inform the design concept of the new remote control
3 - Discuss design options with aim of narrowing down on the design that best suits the market and the project vision
Market Research Findings
#1 consumer desire is that the control have a fancy look and feel not a functional look.
#2 priority of consumers is that the device be technologically innovative
3rd priority was for ease of use.
Top Style Trends
Top European fashion trend is for styles that reflect a fruit and vegetable theme especially in clothes and furniture
Material trends are quickly shifting from hard materials to soft, spongy textures
Style Trend Overview
Style is paramount
Innovative design and technology also a must
Ease of use must be ensured throughout
Vibrant natural colour
Softness in materials, shape and function
Think  mac iPod

Harvest, plantation, seed, lemon, lime, sprout, bean, green, pea,

doc.content:
Final Report
Decisions made in Kick-Off Meeting:
	Product should control multiple devices, eg VCR, DVD, Stereo, etc 
	Product should look good/trendy 
Decisions made in Functional Design Meeting:
	Which requirements were essential, and which were ideal
	Target group = 15-35 age bracket 
	Use of speech recognition - yes
	Product powered by conventional,non-rechargeable batteries
	Grouping products functions into 3 categories - audio, video & other
Decisions made in Conceptual Design Meeting:
	Product will be made of plastic & rubber 
	"Snowman" shape 
	Gimmicky backlighting and LEDs inside case
	No need for "talk back" or LCD
	Jog dial to be incorporated 
	Corporate colour (yellow) to feature heavily in design
	Corporate slogan to feature on product
	
Decisions made in Detailed Design Meeting:
	Due to financial restraints, the LCD & advanced chip were removed from the design
	The final prototype was produced.
	
	Final Design:
	
	The final design is a snow man shape, of dimensions 10x3x2.5 cm.
	The materials used are yellow, blue and red plastic.
	Push buttons and an integrated scroll wheel/ pushbutton were used for input.
	The companys logo and slogan are printed on the device.
	Batteries are the only power source.
	Functionalities are: Volume control, Power on/off, visual settings (brightness, contrast), channel tuning, auxiliary input settings, sounds settings (bass, treble, balance, pre-programmed sound modes).
	Cost of final design is 12.4 euros.

Minutes of the Meeting of Real Reaction
12.00 pm
13.12.04
Meeting Room
Present: 	David
		Craig
		Andrew
		Laura
Laura brought the new project requirements to the attention of the team.
David, Craig and Andrew delivered their presentations.
The following decisions were made:
The target group for the project will be 15-35 year olds.
The functionalities of the remote control will be divided into 3 categories: audio, video and other.
Speech recognition will be implemented as part of the user interface.
The remote control will be powered by conventional, non-rechargeable batteries.

Minutes of the Meeting of Real Reaction
14.10 pm
13.12.04
Meeting Room
Present: 	David
		Craig
		Andrew
		Laura
David, Craig and Andrew gave their presentations.
Discussion of the following topics took place:
Shape of product  snowman shaped
Colour  predominantly yellow
Corporate slogan to feature on product casing
Plastic & rubber to be used
Back-lighting for buttons and LEDs to shine through casing
A jog dial to be implemented for scrolling through channels
No need for either a talk back function or an LCD
Power to be kinetic, with battery back up.

Minutes of the Meeting of Real Reaction
15.30 pm
13.12.04
Meeting Room
Present: 	David
		Craig
		Andrew
		Laura
The prototype was presented and discussed.
The evaluation criteria were discussed.
The production cost of the remote control was calculated, and some design features (LCD & extra material) were removed to keep to the budget.
The design process was evaluated:
Room for creativity: financial and time constraints meant that creative process was a bit confined.  A more relaxed environment (without headsets, etc) might have been more conducive to creativity.
Leadership: personal coach, project manager, etc meant for a lot of structure  perhaps too much.
Team work: would have been easier if we could have communicated outside meetings.  Tools available to us didnt really support collaboration.  The actual work involved was quite isolated.
Means: would have preferred to use the whiteboard more, and powerpoint less.  Too many presentations.  Digital pens are quite chunky but easy enough to use.  Computers provided distraction in meetings.  Play dough very useful.

Minutes of the Meeting of Real Reaction
11.00 am
13.12.04
Meeting Room
Present: 	David
		Craig
		Andrew
		Laura
The team introduced themselves to each other.
The team familiarised themselves with the equipment, e.g. whiteboard, microphones, projectors.
Project finances were discussed, e.g. production costs and selling price.
The following topics were discussed:
The product may be vary in popularity according to geographical area because of its price.
Technical query  do we need to consider different zones (like DVD regions)
In present market, what kind of remote control can be bought for 25 euro?
Want product to control multiple devices.
Extra functionalities could include controlling lighting, making  notes about programmes you want to watch.
Personal experiences with remote controls  easily lost.
Want product to look chic
Realise that extra functionalities that could provide selling points will be restricted by production cost.
